Actually, this isn‚Äôt a new story and it‚Äôs occurring more often as EVs become older. There are an increasing number of stories that involve EV owners learning that the battery costs more than the car itself. A lot of these stories could have been avoided if people did their homework about rechargeable batteries, EVs, and being wary of any product that is promoted by government politicians and social activists. First of all, rechargeable batteries have a limited life. They can be recharged for a period of time before they can no longer hold a charge. This is true for all rechargeable batteries; especially power tools. EVs are no different. Many foreign cars, like Toyota and Hyundai, have factories in the countries they sell their cars to. This allows foreign manufacturers to sell their cars internationally for a lower price because they don‚Äôt have to export. This is not the case for EV batteries. One of the main elements to manufacture an EV battery is cobalt. Congo is the primary supplier of this element, and it is obtained via black child slave labor. This isn‚Äôt a secret‚Ä¶it‚Äôs just isn‚Äôt talked about for socio-political reasons. Because of the strip mining that is required to obtain cobalt ore and the cost of exporting it, EV batteries are expensive. Government subsidies don‚Äôt make it cheaper. Part of an article from MIT (yes that one):  Currently, most lithium is extracted from hard rock mines or underground brine reservoirs, and much of the energy used to extract and process it comes from CO2-emitting fossil fuels. Particularly in hard rock mining, for every tonne of mined lithium, 15 tonnes of CO2 are emitted into the air.  Battery materials come with other costs, too. Mining raw materials like lithium, cobalt, and nickel is labor-intensive, requires chemicals and enormous amounts of water‚Äîfrequently from areas where water is scarce‚Äîand can leave contaminants and toxic waste behind. 60% of the world‚Äôs cobalt comes from the Democratic Republic of the Congo, where questions about human rights violations such as child labor continue to arise.  Manufacturing also adds to these batteries‚Äô eco-footprint, Shao-Horn says. To synthesize the materials needed for production, heat between 800 to 1,000 degrees Celsius is needed‚Äîa temperature that can only cost-effectively be reached by burning fossil fuels, which again adds to CO2 emissions.

The rest of the car consists of a planetary gear that connects the electric motors to the driveshafts and then you have all the electric stuff that never wears out because there is no motion meaning NO FRICTION..! I can‚Äôt believe the number of idiots that are claiming the invoice is a typo. You obviously have no idea how pricing and invoicing works. The list price is $56,649.98. The big problem that‚Äôs identified here is the cost of vehicle parts. This is true regardless if you‚Äôre buying an ICE vehicle or electric. If you bought an $60k ICE vehicle for example, and were to build that exact same care entirely from parts, your cost (without labour) would likely be in around $200-300k. As someone who‚Äôs done my own repairs on ICE vehicles, that cost inflation is not far from what I‚Äôve experienced in over 40 years across multiple manufacturers.  There is no way a $56k (actual cost) battery in a vehicle that costs $60k means the remaining parts only cost $4k. Consider what those remaining parts are, and go with your wildest underestimation of those costs and you won‚Äôt come up with $4 k remaining unless you‚Äôre sniffing glue. How about a $10k motor and $8k transmission on a car bought for $26k? Sure, the battery cost highlights the issue even more because it is a much greater cost proportionally, as we scramble to adjust the supply to meet the demand in the current market. It doesn‚Äôt change that the issue is the over-inflated parts cost.  I realize there can be costs that inflate that individual part cost, but you cannot be considered ‚Äúreasonable‚Äù to have the sort of inflation we see.  In part the issue has been highlighted here - the fact dealerships are NOT the manufacturer themselves, but effectively retailers who mark up parts costs from the manufacturer. That markup is often in around or in excess of 100%. It is what pays for those shiny, snazzy new buildings. It‚Äôs a cash cow for someone, clearly.

Without reading all the details: Replacement batteries have excessive prices intentionally. They are legally required to sell replacement parts (also batteries!) to everyone who wants them to ensure a free market. The problem is that they also have to keep replacement batteries in storage for 10 or mor years after production ended (although this is not a legal requirement but a pretty standard procedure). So they don't want to sell them to anyone. And this is where the fun begins that applied to EVs since 2009: The replacement pack is sold for 60k and the old pack will be refunded for ~55k on the same bill. So the real cost is ~5k but not the price.  But the other possibility is that dealerships use this as anchor point to sell new vehicles or discourage people from buying EVs.

I don't think it's really weird in a way, because Batteries are really really expensive to begin with. Batteries in China are cheaper than in Canada. Also, mass production and delivery plays a role. Let's put it like this: if i want to have 1 single orange shipped from Valencia, Spain sent all the way to the midwest in America, despite that orange only costing let's say 50 pennies, it'll be like what, 500 USD when it arrives. However, buying that orange locally in Valencia would only be 50 pennies. If you order 10 thousand of them, 5 miles from Valencia, they might only be 30 pennies.  If you take that example, it's pretty logical that a battery(pack) can be more expensive than the entire vehicle if you switch the orange to batteries, especially if you have to include the labor to remove the old battery ( which is complicated ), then install the new battery, and have a 'warranty' on it.  It's not about being bonkers, it's about explaining the process.   Also, if we consider that EV batteries are essentially an integral part of the 'engine' of an EV, then if that fails, it needs a 'new' engine. Now if you take a brand new VW Golf, let's say that's 30k USD. if the engine goes stink, and needs replacement, well, a brand new VW Golf engine - not a second hand, used, older one, no a literal brand new one, complete, not just a component, but the entire thing including transmission, i think easily will set you back 15k USD. easily. then it involves man hours to mount, etc. so i assume you'd spend like 20k for a replacement there too.   Yes, that's not the same as the total vehicle cost, but it's again an example to show how the 'finances' work, taking into account EV's are 'behind' in service and maintainence compared to ICE vehicles, especially the ease on replacing things.   Is it bonkers in the end - sure. Should you get a lawyer and sue Hyundai for this? Hell yes.  I'm not really surprised to be honest. These things however 'need' to happen and 'will' happen until in a decade or two times will change and have improved for the EV market to become better maintainable.

This sounds like this could have been a great deal for Kyle. So I know it looks like very minor damage, a lot of folks might be thinking why would they condemn a battery?  I work in the heavy duty truck industry as a technician. Cummins put on a training seminar one year at a TMC meeting on aftertreatment systems (Diesel oxidation catalysts, Diesel particulate filters, and SCR catalysts). They said that one of the most common causes of failure of these devices is the vehicle taking impact damage, not necessarily a direct impact to the component. We are talking about fragile components made from ceramic. If an SCR catalyst is cracked it is not a dangerous situation, it will cause premature failure of the catalyst but you don't have to worry about the truck burning to the ground. A battery in an electric vehicle is a complex component with roughly 7000 individual cells, multiple controllers to charge/discharge the battery, monitor cell condition and balance cell charge, etc. I don't blame a dealership for condemning a component that could defect internally that you cannot see because of impact damage, you have no idea how hard the bottom of that car was hit. If they were to tell that customer everything is fine don't worry about it and a couple months later that car burns his house down because there was a damaged cell in a pack, now the dealership and the technician become liable, maybe not criminally but in civil court they could get their asses handed to them.

Ample is a new electric vehicle charging system which works by having robots quickly replace small modular battery packs in electric cars, getting them back on the road in a few minutes, not unlike a gasoline fill-up. Unlike prior efforts at battery swap, Ample‚Äôs system is lower cost, more flexible and most importantly is aimed at commercial fleets and taxis, not ordinary drivers. Ample states it has partnerships with 5 OEMs with 9 different electric vehicles to use or be adapted for their modular battery packs, and it will be opening its low-cost swap stations in cities with heavy electric fleet operations. In videos it shows a Mercedes, Nissan Leaf and Kia Niro, and it also will partner with Uber.

worked in a body shop as a painter... one thing that the average person doesn't know. manufactures have what's called "repair procedures".. for example, it basically tells the technician how to do the work i.e (where to cut, where to reweld ect).. if these manufactures have a "repair procedure" that calls for "battery replacement" ....legally(in the U.S, idk Canada laws), they can't repair the car without replacing the battery. this is a manufacture issue, not a body shop issue. just wanted to make that clear for anyone wondering.

I can understand the cost. It's all to do with the parts. The battery is produced to go in the particular vehicle. Batteries are around 60-70% of the cost of the car itself. Unlike a shelf full of brake pads or oil filters or other components, a battery is not an off the shelf part. It's a specific factory order part. They are not going to stop the production line and take a battery pack from a vehicle in production. They don't have the capacity to produce extra batteries especially as the cost rises every single year for the materials in the battery. It's just not cost effective to build spare batteries.Therefore for the manufacturer, it's more cost effective to overprice the battery making the vehicle a write off and letting the insurance company foot the bill and you in turn pay higher premiums.

While electric vehicles, including popular models like Tesla, are seen as efficient and environmentally friendly, owning an EV for about 10 years might not be cheaper than traditional gasoline cars, except for luxury cars that often have high maintenance costs. After about 5 years, the battery in an EV tends to lose about 25% efficiency due to climate conditions, especially extreme cold in the northern hemisphere (which can affect it even more) and extreme heat above 35 degrees Celsius, impacting efficiency and posing a higher risk of fire. Companies like Toyota and Volkswagen are waiting to invest more in new electric vehicle technology until batteries become more advanced, surpassing the efficiency of combustion engines and the materials used for fuel. By the way, producing just one battery pack for a Tesla creates a carbon footprint equivalent to running a diesel engine continuously for a whole year. Regards from Oxford University of Materials study department.

According to Recurrent, the average EV battery price per kWh is $135/kWh since 2020 (projected to be ~$60/kWh by 2030). With a normal battery size of 60kWh that's $8k. Now, there's a HUGE variation in price per manufacturer. E.g. BMW's batteries cost roughly $700/kWh to replace. On the other hand Nissan chargers around $150/kWh. And some dealers also upcharge a lot on top. E.g. GM lists their price at ~$250/kWh, which is $16k for a Bolt EV (65kWh) - but there's been dealers quoting $30k. That's one of the reasons why I wouldn't buy an EV from legacy auto manufacturers. They're selling their vehicles at a huge loss for compliance reasons, and their dealers can be very greedy. It may very well bite you when you need to replace the battery.

Mechanic here from over the pond in the UK so not sure if it's the same as over there. In the UK there's a lot of stipulation around the repair of EVs when they've been damaged, for example you have to store them 100m away from any other cars or buildings, when brought in for repair you need to cordon off that area of the workshop and the technician themselves need to be high voltage trained. All of this makes repairing of EVs impractical and expensive, often causing companies to loose money on a job, inevitably this means repair centres and insurance companies aren't inclined to carry out repairs as its not financially viable. Often times these 1 or 2 year old EVs that have had minor damage get written off by the insurance companies and goes to sit in a storage depo until they figure out what to do with it as from that point onwards they are considered a hazard. The ridiculous price given for repair is basically them saying we're not interested, try somewhere else.

Years ago I hit a large patch of black ice on a corner. I went off the road and ended up with the car sitting on it's floor pan, and both front wheels dangling over the edge of a ditch (Luckily not far enough that it was in danger of toppling in). A passing driver stopped and towed my car back onto the road, and after putting the spare wheel on I drove it home.  Next day I had a look at it in daylight and couldn't see anything too bad, mostly just the shattered bumper, and large patches of underseal scraped off the floor, but when I took it out for a test drive I felt it was ever so slightly more sluggish than it had been before. It wasn't drastic, and I couldn't really tell if I was imagining it, but it just felt a little slower getting up to the speed limit. Turns out that I'd put a small dent along the leading edge of the floor pan, and that was in just the right place to stop the throttle (Gas) pedal from being able to go it's last 1/2" of travel. once I realised this I pulled out the carpet and "Precisely massaged" the metalwork back into shape using a scrap piece of wooden fence post and a sledgehammer......... Good as new ! :D  Anyway, Here in the UK, hitting ice and sliding off the road is SUCH a common type of accident to happen during bad winters that it makes me wonder if EV manufacturers should be legally obliged to prove that their cars have adequate battery protection in place when they get them type approved? Maybe they need to also have a "Road debris and bottoming out" battery impact test while they're having all the other crash safety tests done?  It's REALLY not acceptable to have such an expensive, damage intolerant, and potentially dangerous part of a car just bolted to an area where it can so easily take a knock............ And yes, before anyone says it, I know ICE cars have fuel tanks equally exposed, but the difference is that the average fuel tank (Not counting the ridiculously designed "Ford Pinto) can get pretty horrendously mangled before it poses any kind of safety risk, it's a smaller target to get damaged, and if it IS compromised it's usually pretty obvious. Where as the battery shown here had what most would consider a cosmetic "Ding", but was still deemed too dangerous to be on the road.

I have never heard of this before, but I work in IT and I am not surprised. If you ever look at the warranties on computers, the extended warranties from big brands such as Lenovo and Dell, they do not cover batteries because they are usually the first thing to go. (Apple is worse, but not the point) If a laptop is well cared for, usually, the battery is the first thing to go and there are defiantly bad batches of batteries where certain models of laptop will all have their batteries fail/expand years before they should.  Another issue with this is buttery production. At least for computers, batteries are usually only produced when the computer is made. So if you ever need to replace the battery, it's probably a surplus battery from the original production meaning the battery is already years old when you go to replace it. I hope that's not true for cars, but I had not thought about it until now.  This also has me worried about some of the other issues we see with computers/warranties/bad software updates in IT which could become more relevant to cars. This story is BS.  There are three possible parts of this story that aren't told.   1) the Driver is lying to avoid responsibility for their own idiocy and the damage is much more than he suggests.  2) the Dealer is being shady  3) the Manufacturer has a significant design flaw (by accident or intent) that may require regulations to ensure that it is not in future models.   None of these outcomes is Electric Cars aren't sustainable.  The Owner would have had to bottom the car out HARD to do enough damage to need a battery replacement... to the point that it wasn't a few scratches and damage to the battery was done. That is significant damage and that means the guy just doesn't want to take responsibility for it. It be like bottoming out a car to the point the entire exhaust and fuel tank was damaged. If that is the case this person is literally trying to cover up their own negligence and blaming EV's for them being an idiot.   The Alternative is the plate is damaged but the battery is fine. The plate should be able to be replaced without replacing the whole battery. This means one of two things. Either the manufactures are taking short cuts to repairability or the dealership is screwing over the customer because they don't want to do the work and are trying to over charge.   The two possibilities means that more work needs to be done to deal with bad dealers and regulation of battery covers is needed to ensure they are replaceable without replacing the whole battery. This would be a situation where a manufacturer screwed up the design. It has nothing to do with sustainability or a failure of Electric cars as a whole. This is the same BS that Farmers deal with where they have to pay a technician to come out to fix a tractor rather than doing it themselves.
This is not only an issue with the battery replacement pricing but also the warranty system.  Something striking the bottom of the car and leaving a scratch, should not void warranty... The damage, as shown, is consistent with Kyle leaving the pavement. One does not end up with gravel embedded in body panels by impacting an object on a paved road. That is unless that object is ice or compaceted snow with gravel embedded within or a pile of gravel. In this instance, again based on the single photo, it appears Kyle either hit a pothole, was driving on a rough gravel road, or went off the road onto a soft shoulder where gravel became embedded in the plastic panel.   The plastic panel ,(protective cover) is fastened in several spots. If any of those plastic fasteners come loose or are broken, say due to impact, the panel is going to sag where the fastener broke or came loose. Debris filling the void could also cause sagging of the panel. Gap widening between the plastic panel and the battery pack does not automatically indicate an issue with the battery pack. Further investigation is required to determine the cause of the widened gap.  Transition to EVs is outpacing mechanic training. This could be a case of a mechanic not fully understanding the vehicle he was task with inspecting. Hence relying solely on a bulletin to determine a course of action; widened gap = automatic battery replacement.   My take away: rather than pulling into a dealership for battery concerns I will find an EV specialty shop to inspect the battery first. An EV shop would do both a physical inspection for damage and run diagnostics to check for signs of internal damage.....all without reporting their findings to the manufacturer. I have a Hyundai story from 1997. My wife, before we married had bought a Hyundai Excel in 1994. We married in 1997. In 1997 while driving to work the transmission failed, luckily the Hyundai dealership was very close, so she limped the car into their service department. They told her that the car was just outside its 3 year warranty by 3 months and to replace the transmission would cost $5600. The car had cost her $21000 so basically a third of the entire cost of a new vehicle. My wife rang me at work and was very upset, i told her not to worry and I made an appointment with the dealer principal. When we met him i told him that I had replaced a number of transmissions on General Motor Holden cars over my driving life time and none had cost a third of the vehicle cost. He had a conference with his staff and came back with an offer to replace the transmission for $1900, with a 12 month warranty. He said as the car was only 3 months out of its warranty this was a good will gesture on their part. We accepted the deal. A few months later I heard through my service mechanic that the transmissions in the Excel model had a very high fail rate but Hyundai had not done a recall. So it was a common problem. We sold the car soon after and I persuaded my wife to buy a Toyota, like myself and she had another 20 years trouble free motoring, with several different Toyota models, a Camry and a Kluger. I have owned over the years a Corolla, a Camry Wagon , a Camry sedan and currently own a Kluger. I wouldn't take a Hyundai of any model as a free prize in a raffle.

I‚Äôve dealt with building fires, and it is often cheaper after a fire to simply replace all the wiring instead of spending time to figure out where the problem may be and fixing that small problem. Since the EV batteries are a single unit constituting of many different little batteries, it could be easier and cheaper to simple replace the entire battery than figure out what part of the battery is damaged.   No one that knows electrical systems will give you a 100% assurance that even an impacted battery may not be a future problem that would open a company up to severe liability if indeed there was a problem. There is no way of knowing that without spending large sums of money to find out.   This is the dirty little secret about EVs that few want to discuss. These batteries are integral to the structure of the car, therefore battery damage can be equivalent to bending the frame of a car. You can indeed fix a bent frame, but it would be more expensive than a new car.

Still a lot of growing pains for EVs that need to be resolved. And the single biggest hurdle by far, is the batteries... We need cheaper, cleaner (to manufacture) and more reliable battery solutions! These Li-Ion batteries are a liability in each and every electric car today, whether the battery has been impacted or not. And how many of these cases actually get reported? How many cars are driving around that had their battery impacted in one way or another and we don't know about it, even the owners don't know about it?  Li-Ion batteries are extremely dirty and expensive to manufacture and they all have a dangerously high combustion risk... It's NOT a very good solution for EVs.  I love the idea of EVs, but their current battery technology is a disaster waiting to happen.  We've seen petrol driven Land-Rover Discoverys and Ford Kugas go up in flames. It is far more scary watching a Li-Ion battery car burn up.  Better battery solution technologies do exist, but because of the already huge investments made into producing more Li-Ion Batteries the battery manufacturers are not keen to switch. Also the additional cost to switch and re-tool the factories in order to produce these improved batteries seem prohibitive, but could be more cost effective in the long run, yet no-one looks in the long term anymore. Everyone wants to make as much money as they can, today.  Also, if Lithium mines have to reduce production, many will become unprofitable rather quickly. Lithium prices have to remain high for most of the mines to remain economically viable. It's become a vicious circle which is very difficult to just turn away from.

I just want to give a little insight to how it works at a dealership. I‚Äôm an Audi technician, I am also HVT certified meaning I work on EVs. Warranty only covers parts replacement on parts that have failed prematurely due to manufacture quality. When we replace parts under warranty Audi‚Äôs head quarters in Germany then takes those parts back and test them to ensure we in fact did replace failed parts. In this case if the dealer would have replaced the battery under warranty when Hyundai asks for the battery pack back and they see an outside influence (the damage from the customer hitting somthing in the road) the claim would have been kicked back and the dealer would be responsible for the $60,000 battery. It is not Hyundais or the dealer‚Äôs responsibility to replace parts damaged due to outside influence. You also said that why didn‚Äôt the dealer take battery pack out to inspect it. Idk if y‚Äôall understand how technicians get paid but we get paid flag hours not hourly. Who would pay the technician to remove the battery pack? Warranty would not. The customer wouldn‚Äôt pay to remove the battery pack because they can‚Äôt afford to replace the battery in the first place. Also not to mention the time to replace any part under warranty is awful on most jobs and almost undoable. When a customer pays for a part replacement the technician gets paid the correct amount of hours to complete the job

This is absurd. If the $60k battery needs to be replaced after such a minor scrape to its outer casing like this, then Hyundai has manufactured an item that is NOT fit for purpose. In Canada we have laws that specifically protect us in these situations. The Consumer Protection Act states that goods must be fit for their purpose when sold, and also continue to be so for a reasonable amount of time after the sale (depending on the purpose, price paid, etc). If this doesn‚Äôt happen, then the CPA says there is a ‚Äúpresumption of latent defect‚Äù, i.e. the item was defective prior to sale. Hyundai needs to replace this at their cost or face a class action claim that covers everyone affected by this issue. Both Kyle and ICBC should be claimant in the suit. That‚Äôs the only way that Hyundai and other EV sellers will be prevented from ripping off customers and their insurers in this manner.

This should serve as a warning to anyone considering buying an EV. I have a fair amount of experience with rechargeable batteries of various sizes, in various applications, particularly in standby/backup power systems for homes and businesses. What always dogged me was the universally short lifespan of such batteries. In my experience, nearly all rechargeable batteries last only two to three years before needing replacement. It doesn't seem to much matter what battery chemistry is involved (Li-ion, NiMH, Ni-Cd, etc.). They all have a very limited lifetime.   Even if a replacement EV battery were only around say, $5,000 That would still stop me cold in buying any EV or battery hybrid. Perhaps some third-party extended warranty policies provide adequate coverage for this? No, I'll wait for either battery technology, or dealer customer relations policy, to improve.

Follow the VIN #. 10 to 1 odds this vehicle ends up back on the market as a certified pre-owned vehicle with a new battery cover. It sounds like the dealership scammed Kyle out of his car. Here's how it works; The dealership gets in a car with minor damage. They then declare a major component of that car that they know will make the car a total loss (in this case the battery) as damaged beyond repair. The insurance company takes title of the vehicle as part of the insurance payout for a total loss. The dealership then purchases the car for scrap value from the insurance company, which of course they are happy to do because it takes the vehicle off of their hands and they no longer have to deal with it. The money Kyle gets does not go to him, it goes to his finance company to clear his debt which allows them to release the title to the insurance company. Now they can legally resale the car back to the dealership. If Kyle gets anything it's probably in the form of a credit to put a down payment on a new vehicle. However, more often than not, Kyle gets a bill for the balance the insurance company did not cover from his finance company. The car then gets it's minor damage fixed by the dealer and gets resold as a certified pre-owned vehicle. There's a few more nuances to this "total out" hustle, like the fact that Kyle now has to pay a lot more for insurance for the next 10 years, etc.. But you get the picture.

Just design a floor plate, where a chosen number of standardised cells can be placed, like six for a normal vehicle. Then when one cell is generally sufficient for your daily commute you are already saving on raw materials several times over. And when you do need the occasional longer range, then take the full six. Swaps cost little more than 5 minutes, comparable to filling gas. I know suspension needs to be based on air this way, to be able to compensate for the additional weight, but you can overcome these little hurdles easily.

The dealership and Hyundai‚Äôs approach stems from liability avoidance.  From their perspective, it makes sense to advise battery replacement than be liable for giving a potentially damaging battery the all clear. (Plus there‚Äôs money to be made from fitting a new battery).  As an electrical engineer with a lot battery experience , I‚Äôd thoroughly test the battery: assess charge/discharge characteristics at maximum rated ambient temperature, look for deformation and swelling in the area of impact, use a thermal camera to detect abnormal hot and cold spots. Nio is a Chinese automaker that offers an alternative to charging: just swapping out the whole battery whenever you need it.  This needs to become the standard practice. The three main complaints that ICE drivers have against electric vehicles are 1) Cost of battery replacement 2) Charge range and 3) Charging time compared to gas.   What NIO has accomplished is to make charging faster than filling a tank of gas, eliminate the need to buy a new battery if one goes bad, and introduce a simple infrastructure model that is easy to establish. This is a game changer, but it remains to be seen if the oil industry will invest or impede.   Conservative projections suggest that most, if not all, new cars sold will be electric by 2040. Innovations to solve issues like battery life/replacement are going to be plentiful.

For having been in the parts supply industry. Most car (and appliances too actually) reseller apply a simple x3, x4 or even x5 to the cost of parts. While this makes some sense when you are selling smaller parts and this kind of pricing structure can cover handling and shipping internally (e.g. $1 bolt resold for $4 and so on), it get absolutely ridiculous when you apply this accross the whole parts inventory. It is no wonder expensive parts like full motors, engine, battery packs, seats, full climate boxes or dashboards end up posting ridiculous price. While the battery might indeed cost the dealer $10k or just under that, the automatic x3 or x4 applied to the cost makes the end price absolutely non-sensical and inflate the price beyond the actual car cost as new ($40k+ on this Ionic 5). Cars are sold with very small margins of profits, but spare parts are essentially 75% profit. Don't believe me? Check most online parts stores and see that they have basically a blanket 20% rebate on all parts, including those battery packs! The pricing structure is just applied automatically to ALL PARTS, so that the overall profit margins expressed in % are good. Having spoken with many colleagues in parts department, they will generally apply generous rebates on those large ticket items, as the net benefice is good anyway. Recent example, I bought a new leather covered dashboard which was $6100 CAD, on which the parts manager issued me a 50% rebate no problem on the part. His cost was about $2000 for it, and he felt totally good with having a net profit of $1000 on a single item sale... Tell me the pricing models aren't broken...

It's a knee jerk reaction to the potentially huge issue of a damaged battery.  Lithium based batteries, even the relatively safe (well compared to other lithium battery tech anyway) Lithium Iron (LIFe) batteries used in the vast majority of EV's are known to be very susceptible to thermal runaway issues if damaged. Nobody wants anything to do with that. It's why a lot of insurance companies in the UK will now no longer insure Jaguar/Range Rover EV's or Hybrids. Too many going thermal, or being stolen. The two that still do are asking 10's of thousands of pounds pa to insure. In Australia and the UK it is actually more expensive to fill an EV from a public charging point than to refill an ICE vehicle.  Add in the sheer distances involved in Australia, where you don't get the advantage of regenerative braking, your range is around 25-30% less than the advertised range for any EV, plus it only takes 5 minutes to fill and pay for a completely empty ICE.  There's a recent story of a woman with child having to refill an EV she had hired while on a trip between Sydney and Melbourne.  Middle of the night, after finally managing to find a signal for her phone she was stressed and upset with a very irate child and after 45 minutes still hadn't enough power in the battery to get her to the next (hopefully working) publicly accessible charging point.   Considering the costs in mining, processing the batteries, the massive weight increase that impacts tyre life, and suspension. Here in Australia electricity production is responsible for over 30% of all co2 tonnage, more than the entire transport system. So they are NOT Zero Emission, they are only "Remote Emission" at best. They're only cheaper to run in the narrow band of you being a totally urban motorist, able to charge at home or work, and if you never need to get them serviced, or repaired, and factor in the absolutely terrible resale they currently "enjoy" Maybe when there is true "green" energy production and grid storage, along with an honest breakthrough in battery tech, like "solid state" sodium based (which can be charged much faster and has no thermal runaway issues, even if you drive a spike through them), not the current claimed breakthrough Lithium tech that is at best a small incremental improvement. Well... in a nutshell, this situation is like you have damaged the fuel tank in ICV and there is a threat of leaking the fuel and/or catching fire. The only logical approach is to have the fuel tank replaced. And because the damage was caused by you, the owner, it's again quite logical to pay for the replacement or involve the insurance company. For EVs, alas,  the problem is that the fuel tank costs 60k CAD (or whatever currency equivalent), so the replacement is just a theoretical excercise. We can indeed discuss the quality of the battery protection, but considering the battery location, weight and yet quite low capacity, from technical point of view the protection cannot be like armor plates, but be just a soft protection against water, debris, etc. If you ever happen to hit it hard so that heavy scratches will appear and the structural damage is visible by naked eye, it will not work and I don't think this is just a Hyundai issue. A conclusion? EVs are far from being fit for use or purpose of being a true workhorse. You need to take care, you need to watch carefully where you are driving to. You need to accept that the most precious part of the car is the battery - located very low and close to the ground with barely no real protection at all (valid for all carmakers). And that battery is the equivalent of a fuel tank, filled with fuel even though the car reports it has run out of charge and that it can catch fire due to various reasons. ICVs have their fuel tanks located at the most safest place in the car... guess why?

Production emissions are 20 times higher (mainly because of the batteries and reinforced frame to hold the weight of that huge battery) and to just breakeven, in terms of emissions, vs an ICE (on operation) the EV needs to travel about 120K miles (!!!) on renewable energy charges! Good luck with that (ever) happening when the vast majority of energy in the electricity mix comes from fossil fuels!  Secondly, you keep asking why don't they open the cover to inspect whether the battery has a problem. What they won't admit (and why you never got a sufficient answer from them) is that THEY CAN'T assess the battery even if they do open the cover and inspect it. These batteries have notoriously unstable chemistry and you can never know whether certain elements are now hanging on a thread before triggering a chain reaction of events, catch fire, explode, and so on!  People who run to buy a new product with a new technology should get in terms with the idea that they are becoming Beta testers for the manufacturer and are going to lose money! Car companies always have BS pricing on spare parts. Sure, there is SOME cost in handling and storage of the parts but those cost are overstated. The manufacturers don't want the trouble associated with supplying spares but they are forced to make sure parts are available for a certain amount of time by customer protection laws so they think, well, if we have to do it, we may as well fleece our customers. This is proven by the fact that generic replacement parts are much cheaper. The car companies would claim that these are substandard but that's not at all always the case and sometimes can even be better. Like for like quality, I've found that the branded part can sometimes be several times the cost of the generic part. Car companies have an existing supply chain to allow for extra parts for spares or have the tooling already and they can just make a few more parts. Unfortunately, generic part suppliers have to tool up and therefore they only look after popular brands and high volume models. Still it's interesting that with all the cost of designing an equivalent part, designing and making the tools and setting up production, they can be still a lot cheaper. Spare parts are highway robbery and the example in this video just proves it.

This would not happen in Australia. Our consumer laws are very strict, and the department that manages consumers affairs has real judicial teeth. Interestingly, our laws make the DEALER or SELLER completely responsible for the after sales warranty and care. Consumers are NOT required to contact the manufacturer, and sellers cannot fob them off by telling them to do so. Retailers, dealers and sellers are completely responsible for conforning to consumer laws...which means if they fail in their responsibility the consequences are on them...not the manufacturer. Dealers are fully aware that failing to meet legal obligations on "fair use" (warranty has no meanng under Australian law...only "reasonable fitness for purpose") will lead to legal consequences for them.

We are in the first generation of EV batteries from all manufacturers. Given the complexity of EV systems, I think this is a good reminder that first generation of anything is always an experiment - not just from a manufacturing standpoint, but also from the parts and repair standpoint. The whole supply chain just isn't there to deal with the likely problems from first generation problems. I love and want an EV at some point, but as a consumer not flash with lots of money to be throwing at problems, I think its safe to say it makes sense to wait for the second generation of EV's and EV batteries. My guess is the second generation will be solid state, cheaper to replace, and the repair supply chain will be more robust. That's when I'll buy.

There is an issue here. Unlike most mechanical parts, including fuel tanks, there is no good way to tell if a lithium battery is damaged inside. It could catch fire a week or months later after an accident (this has happened multiple times). And of course those fires can be very dangerous. So, crazy as it seems, the 'official' fix for a possibly damaged battery is replacement. The liability risk (as well as safety risk) is enormous if they decide not to replace the battery--there is no room to make a judgement call. Customers need some protection, whether from the manufacturer, or the insurance companies to cover cases like this without jacking up the driver's insurance.

Nynber one, I am surprised the dealer did NOT contact corporate about this immediaely instead makes a knee jerk judgement for complete battery replacement.  The selling/servicing dealer should be making corporate contact for the customer, not the customer having to do this himself.  If there is a specification for the distance between the protective pan and the battery but the pan damage is superficial, the pan should have been removed for a closer more critical inspection of the battery.  Perhaps under he watchful eye of factory service rep and inspectors.  A simple contact with a road hazard should NOT the the reasoning for a full battery replacement,  As a former factory trained mechanic that advanced to dealer shop manager, ANY time we encountered an unusual situation, an appointment was made with the regional factory warrnaty service representative.  We'd meet with the customer, the service rep and the line mechanics to discuss the findings.  The service rep would on the spot make a judgement call, ususally in the favor of the customer.  Even sometimes going beyond the call of duty when the problem was caused by customer inattention or lack of maintenance.  I recall more than once factory corporate technicians would accompany the service rep to personally inspect the car or in severe odd cases, the car would be shipped to the warranty center for inspection and the customer given a loaner car in the interim.  One thing the owner pointed out is after 8-10 years of service the battery will reach the end of it's useful life.  If that battery replacement exceeds the value of the vehicle, then this car will have no resale or trade in value other than maybe scrap metal value.  Ultimately this does NOT bode well for the future of EV vehicles after a few years of use.

Hyundai is a scam car brand.
what you have to take into account here is that the battery can be a very dangerous part of the car. There have been many instances of battery fires in cars that have had an impact accident to the battery area. In operation Li-Ion batteries get very hot and they have a cooling system running through the battery pack to keep this in check so if anything were to damage that cooling system then the potential for a battery over heat is high. Also if the impact actually damaged one of the battery cells then again the chance of fire becomes higher. There are thousands of individual cells in these batteries and the chemistry involved means that a malfunction starts a thermal runaway situation that causes the different chemicals within the damaged cell to mix and ignite. If that happens then it will spread to other cells very quickly and within a very short time the whole battery will be alight along with the car. Li-ion battery fires at this level are very difficult to extinguish as they are self sustaining by making their own oxygen and on top of that the contents of the fumes is toxic and highly dangerous. Ev battery fires have caused two car carrying ships to sink and a third to be a total write off. They have burnt houses to the ground and destroyed and help destroy a multi story car park at an airport in the UK. The chemical battery fire can reach a much higher temperature than one fed by Gasoline or diesel fuel. So I think what you will see from car companies not wanting to be caught up in very expensive legal fault battles is having a zero tolerance to any damage to the battery or its protection case. There are many cases of individual cars catching fire after running over debris. This why the two biggest car Hire companies in the USA are not buying any more BEVs and are looking to sell the ones they have. Sorry for the long winded answer but most people do not realise just how dangerous the battery is that they are sitting on top of because of its chemistry and the fact that it is in the lowest part of the car because of its size and weight. Its a topic that the EV industry and others do not want to be widely known. We are sleepwalking into a minefield with the proliferation of these cars in our confined city spaces.

If anybody has seen how these batteries are made, they will realise that inside are several thousand individual cells, within several modules. Each one of these individual cells has a chemical reaction going on 24/7, it never stops, whether your charging or not. With so many cells to check and verify there integrity, it makes the process uneconomical from a labour perspective. Someone has to pay for that check, right! So the battery pack itself may not be punctured, because it has the protective tray, but the jolt alone from any impact may be sufficient to affect one or more of the thousands of cells. It boils down to a shift in legal liability, in which the person or company that says the battery is fit for purpose, is then liable for a multi million dollar law suit if the battery catches fire, as they do. It should be noted that any battery pack that is punctured, is a very serious risk of water ingress, shorting and potential fire.

There is a widespread myth that EV's will save the planet and that the electricity to recharge them is cheaper than conventional fossil fuels. The reality is that EV' s are far more damaging to the environment than conventional vehicles. The electricity used to recharge them is not green but is generated by a mix of sources comprised of only 6% wind, solar and biomass. The remaining 94% comes from conventional sources including natural gas, nuclear and hyrdo electric. The transition to EV's requires the cost of building the infrastructure required to provide charging stations to power the millions of vehicles required to replace petroleum powered autos. Ev's also have a much larger carbon footprint than conventional vehicles primarily due to the impact of mining and processing the lithium, cobalt, nickel and other rare earth minerals required to manufacture their batteries. The elephant in the room that no one wants to talk about is the increasing number of incidents of spontaneous combustion of the battery packs of these vehicles resulting in serious fires that are almost impossible to extinguish. The recent loss of two massive RORO ships at sea transporting EV's are just one example as of such fires. They range from Electric scooter (bikes) combustion in apartments, electric busses burning on urban streets and EV's buring homes to the ground after spontaneously combusting in the garage. Mainstream media is doing a very poor job of reporting on such fires.

Story told in the first twenty seconds.
Electric Vehicles, or EVs, Are Not Cars  The government and auto industry wants us to believe that EVs are interchangeable with gas-powered vehicles.  EVs are not a ‚Äúcar‚Äù as we know them. EVs are experimental transportation devices that the government wants us to accept as a car replacement.  I believe the rollout of them was extremely premature. They look like cars, and seem to function like cars, but they are not cars.  Words and their traditional definitions matter.  Using the word car for an EV is misleading. I try to avoid it.  EVs are a completely different machine and when purchasing one that should be our mindset.  Replacements For Vital Machines (Evs For Cars) Must Outperform Their Predecessors To Be Universally Adopted  For a new product or invention, which an EV is, to replace a tried and true significant part of our daily lives, like our cars, it has to be a better choice.  Do EVs outperform cars in all important areas? How should a car replacement be better? 1) Cheaper purchase price, lifetime maintenance and disposal. 2) Better performance, road handling and driving range. 3) As many or more locations to ‚Äúrefuel‚Äù and lower recharging times than refueling. Overall more convenient and time saving than gas powered vehicles. 4) Safer in all ways, including charging away from home. 5) Seamless and transparent replacement for our current experience with cars. 6) EVs should be less expensive to insure. How do EVs stack up in those five categories? 1) EVs are more expensive than gas-powered vehicles. Overall costs over time are much higher for EVs. Even if they were cheaper, the current negative impacts of the loss of convenience and functionality make EVs not worth replacing our cars with experimental replacements. Government subsidies paid to corporations and individuals approach $50,000 per EV. An EV is less functional, yet more expensive? Who thought of this great system? 2) EVs have much higher average horsepower, but other than that the driving experience is not much different and is sometimes deficient. Range anxiety is real and total miles available on a full charge falls terribly behind a full tank of gas. 3) Gas stations are much safer and more convenient than EV charging stations. On the road charging can average ten times longer than refueling with gasoline. EVs fail miserably here. 4) The level of danger using an unmanned EV charging station at night in a deserted parking lot is not tenable, compared to gas stations which have personnel, lights and security cameras. EV battery explosions are commonplace. 5) EVs are not a cheaper, more functional replacement for our cars. 6) A true car replacement would be cheaper to insure. Middle class families already can‚Äôt afford car insurance.   EVs fail on almost every measure.  This certainly does not make a great case for EVs.  Using EVs dramatically changes your entire driving experience, one of the most important parts of our daily lives.  There are so many unanswered questions about the impact on us if the government were to ban gas-powered vehicles in favor of EVs.  Mandating EVs will change our way of life.  As with other government experiments in the recent past, they want us to be the test subjects.  I propose we opt out of this government experiment and all others in the future.  Fad For Wealthier People  EVs are still a fad for wealthier people for the most part. Currently they are mostly an option for owners of free standing single family homes and less often owners of townhouses with a garage.  And even for those free standing single family homeowners, once you have more than one EV, it can quickly become impractical, cumbersome and unworkable.  There are government laws forcing apartment complex owners and townhouse communities to allow residents to install charging stations, but they are not widely used.  The vast majority of renters and townhouse owners don‚Äôt have the ability to purchase an EV as they can‚Äôt charge them nightly.  EVs require access to a power supply that can extend to your EV where they are parked overnight. While away from home needing a charge, you need to find a charging station.  For people who own free standing homes, with a traditional garage and driveway setup, this is relatively simple and most practical. But even then, a family with two or more EVs may not be able to charge all of them overnight. Once you expand beyond one EV, things begin to fall apart.  Many townhouse owners are in the same predicament as apartment renters. Renters of any type of home usually don‚Äôt have the ability or finances to install the systems needed to charge an EV. They would also need permission from the landlord.  Even if an apartment complex or townhouse association installed a few, having this done on mass scale for all apartment and townhouse residents is not practical for decades to come, if at all.  Townhouses, although purchased as a residence, are more likely to be a temporary stop to a free standing home, and so installing a charging station may not be worth the investment.  Excluding these drivers will stall or make impossible the complete replacement of gas-powered vehicles with EVs.   So, what percentage of drivers are in free standing single family homes? This is the true market for EVs on the consumer level. And, again, only for one EV in the family.  Let‚Äôs take a look at the figures below.  It will tell us what % of us have severe barriers to entering the EV space.  132,000,000 (A) - USA Households			            	 83,000,000 (B) - Detached single family homes						 49,000,000 (C=A -B) - USA Households With Barriers To Entry Into EV Space	                 37.12% (D=C/A) - % USA Households With Barriers To Entry Into EV Space 233,000,000 (E) - Drivers In The USA			 86,000,000	(D√óE) - USA Drivers With Barriers To Entry Into EV Space			  86,000,000 out of 233,000,000 U.S. drivers cannot practically transition to EV use.   This 37% of drivers who cannot use an EV is important to remember, as it impacts the rest of the problems EV owners face.  Safety Issues At Charging Stations On The Road  Again, remember, we are imagining a world where gasoline is no longer needed and so gas stations would become a novelty.  So, with only EVs in everyday use, there will be times we need to charge away from home. Where will this take place? There is some EV charging infrastructure built out, but there are many problems. And this is with a very small percentage of EVs on the road.  Imagine, again, that only EVs were allowed. The infrastructure needed is unfathomable.  And what is the infrastructure for remote charging going to look like?  I have serious concerns here as should you.  When we need gas, we simply find an open gas station.  Gas stations have security cameras and personnel when they are open.  We take these well lit locations with employees and security cameras for granted. These safety features do not exist at EV charging locations. Most will be in parking lots of retail shopping centers with no attendants.  This decreases security and increases waiting times.  That is what they are proposing. We should not accept these severe regressions of course.   Parents, let me ask you. Would you accept your children going into dark and empty parking lots, when retail stores are closed, to charge up for 20 or 30 minutes by themselves with no personnel on site?  Of course you would not.  No security. No one in government is talking about this. Remember, they want to eliminate the safe gas stations that are an integral part of our culture and replace them with this.  This is just another barrier I don‚Äôt hear anyone discussing.  EVs are not interchangeable with gas-powered vehicles. They are a completely different machine. They are not cars.  Consumers need to demand the same level of security measures and functionality that gas stations provide.

There are lots of problems with EVs lurking under the surface of eco-friendly driving. In this context, the problem is lithium-ion batteries are fairly fragile. If an EV is in an accident, even if the battery compartment itself was not damaged, the shock of the accident may have damaged one or more cells of the battery. This kind of damage may not be identifiable through a visual inspection. Nor is it always possible for a technician identify the damage by running tests on the battery. It may look and behave as a 'good' battery. Yet, some day the damaged cell may start to heat up and catch fire. If that happens, the rest of the cells in the battery will likely catch fire, too. The heat from these fires is very intense and the fires cannot be put out using common firefighting techniques. If an EV catches fire in an underground parking garage, the intense heat can cause the floors above it to collapse.  All of this means that the only safe course to take when an EV's battery MAY have been damaged is to replace it.   Obviously, this is potentially a huge problem for EV owners, insurance companies, and the manufacturers. A simple fender bender could total an EV. The cost of repair between EVs and traditional vehicles can be huge. More people need to be aware of this fact.

This discussion is a complete cluster.  The issue is simple, and very little here is different from ICE vehicles.  First, the manufacturers warranty applies to defects in the vehicle, through design and assembly.  The warranty does not cover road hazard or other damages caused by the operation of the vehicle.  Second, damage caused by the operation of the vehicle may be covered by ICBC.  A claim will result in a change in the insured's discount, assuming the insured has a discount for good driving.  That's understood when you purchase insurance.   So the real issue is whether or not the battery is in fact damaged and requires replacement.  To advise replacement of a $60K component one would expect careful diagnosis to be confident that replacement is required.  That has obviously not been done.  Neither the dealer, nor Hyundai, nor ICBC has evaluated the present battery for failure, either impending or immediate. I Think you guys are missing the point about the dealers perspective .   From my understanding of what you have presented , is that the battery case suffered an impact on the protective case , but the dealer while inspecting noted some deformation around one of the internal case bolts ( stretching),  obviously these battery packs are not just slapped together on a production line , they would be made in a specialised area just for the battery assembly and testing at wherever the battery was sourced from , these battery packs are made up of hundreds or even thousands of cells and  are not an item dealers would be equipped to repair , and  given the complexity and specialised materials are very expensive, and given the delicate nature of the package , it would be impossible for the dealer to guarantee that the impact sustained to the pack will not cause a catastrophic event down the track , as they do not have crystal ball, and are not equipped to dismantle the whole battery pack and check for any potential fail points. And this is yet another one of the big problem s with all EVs. The complex nature of the rechargeable batteries in manufacturing, the high cost of raw materials, , one has to question the notion that EVs are in any way clean given everything about the batteries suck , they are heavy , they are labour intensive and costly to source the raw materials for them , they take a long time to charge , the range still sucks , and that range will diminish as they age and eventually require a huge in cost replacement, and due to this older EVs are going to depreciate like crazy , and you can guarantee, no one is going to want to replace a $20000 dollar battery on a ten year old EV , let alone a 30 , 40 , or 50,000 dollar battery for a 10 year old electric car. And that leads me to my final question, what is going to happen to masses of 10/12 year old EVs that no one wants , and no one wants spend the coin on a new battery ?  A lot of people keep their conventional cars for decades , because they are built to be able to be fully repairable and easily serviced with minimal cost , unlike EVs. This battery is not a regular battery like the one in a flashlight or mobile phone. In an EV car, the battery IS the car more or less, so it's expected to cost a lot. And it's not easy to test a damaged battery and say with high level of confidence if it'll explode or not as a result of the damage. An EV battery is a complex system, not just a plastic box with some metals inside. So it's not surprising that the dealer doesn't want to assume the liability of something going terribly wrong, and instead chooses to play it safe.

I am a hyundai EV technician very familiar with the Ioniq 5. The large EV batteries are bolted to the bottom of these cars in a way that it takes up the entire undercarriage of the vehicle. From about where the driver sits to just before the rear wheels. This does not leave a lot of room for road debris or road hazards to strike the bottom of the vehicle. We have all involuntary hit something on the road before with our gas cars. Its inevitable. If the vehicle impacts something on the road it can compromise that battery. Think of 350 cell phone batteries all bolted to the bottom of your car, inside of a metal case, thats all it is. The general consumer might not understand why the "cover" that is mentioned cant simply be removed for inspection. These batteries are 400 to 500 volts DC current. Its the same reason you cant pry open your new iphone with basic tools and replace the battery. They are very dangerous and can kill someone if handled improperly. Nothing the dealership told this customer is incorrect. There is no service procedure by Hyundai to inspect the battery, the cover mentioned below the battery is not an access cover. It is the bottom case of the battery, it is not servicable or removable, these are decisions the manufacturer makes, these are the things in my opinion that a consumer needs to research and fully understand before buying an EV. There is also no warranty coverage on a vehicle that has impact damage. These are facts. And if customer want to own an EV these are things they need to educate themselves on. No one has to buy an EV. No one has to buy a Hyundai. So at the end of the day if a consumer buys a product and then uses that product in a manner unintended by the manufacturer such as hit a rock and bottom out the vehicle, press the case into the battery. Than that is on the consumer. Why would that be warranty coverage? No different than if you had a new iphone and happened to drop it on its screen while using it and break the screen. Its not warrantable and I think the biggest issue is misinformed consumers that dont fully understand what owning an EV means in terms of driving habbits as well as cost of ownership.
Even if the battery was only potentially replaceable after a considerable period like a decade, it would, as the owner said, totally eliminate any used value. 1:30 - I think the obvious scrapes, dents and scratches to the car's underbody protection plates only indicate a part of the potential problem, and it's something that fans of EVs are keen to dismiss or overlook because it's a problem without a solution.  The garage didn't remove the protection panels to check the battery itsef for damage because it didn't need to. The damage to the protection plating was enough to condemn the vehicle.  Although there need be no visible physical trauma to the battery pack itself - no gouges or splits - the force required to affect the protective shielding in the manner shown must also have been transmitted into the battery cells.  There's no way to tell if the pack has been affected by the g-forces generated by the bumps and scrapes that damaged the car's underbody protection. It may not look serious, but you can't assess invisible internal trauma just by looking. The pack is crammed full of welds, joints, connections and sensors which have been subjected to an unknown amount of force.  Just because an accident isn't severe enough to trigger a car's airbags doesn't mean that it can be ignored.  Of course, it's most likely that everything will be fine and the EV's battery will continue to work as before... But there's a chance that something has cracked or been dislodged to the extent that in two weeks or two months or two years the battery will fail catastrophically.  It might happen. Probably won't, but it might. So the safe option is to scrap the car. Write it off. Incredible, but true.  That's why mechanics and insurance companies are so wary of EVs. Nobody knows exactly what a lithium battery pack is going to do because nobody knows how it's been treated.  In human terms, it's very much like being involved in a violent accident. Doctors can treat broken bones, contusions, haemorrhaging, and all the other trauma from the impact. But what about brain damage? There's nothing to see, and you can appear perfectly rational months after the accident.  But who's to say that, at some point in the future, you won't suffer from mental problems which cause you to act in uncharacteristic ways. You might develop a phobia about the colour blue. Or you might suffer from blackouts. Or you might become depressed or forgetful or even violent.  An apparently sound lithium battery pack could have an unexpected 'breakdown', too. üî•üëÄ

Why is this a Hyundai problem?  The owner hit something.  The battery is damaged as a result.  The gap between battery and cover has increased, so either the cover has dropped, unlikely, or the battery above has been hit upwards.  A lithium ion battery that has had impact damage is a ticking time bomb.  Vehicle warranty is to cover manufacturing defects.  This is not a manufacturing defect, this is impact damage.  If he'd scraped the body along a wall, he or his insurance company get to pay for that repair, not Hyundai.  So why whinge about an impacted battery?  If an ICE car had hit something and punctured the oil pan, the oil run out, and the engine suffered irreparable damage, that would be on the driver, not the vehicle manufacturer. Replacement parts costs will always add up to more than a car's value.  Components for the production line are manufactured in bulk, delivered in containers, no retail packaging.  Replacement parts are manufactured in smaller numbers, (more cost per item), individually packaged (more cost), then sat on shelves incurring funding costs, all of which have to be included in the sale price. So unfair to rail against Hyundai, or any manufacturer in this situation.

Hi guys I did a bit of research on battery prices on a 2023 Volkswagen id4 rear wheel drive with the big battery and the complete battery pack assembly part number 11K 915 910 CA IS  $ 52,342.00 the make of the battery cell are LG but replaced cell modules are available part number 0Z1 915 599 J price each is $ 2,526.00 there are 12 in total so for the cells alone would be $ 30,312.00 so the rest is the battery case and some wires but it‚Äôs very unlikely the a vehicle would need all of them at the same time and the battery protective plate called under bar is not very expensive $ 1,611.00 most likely what the ionic 5 would need to repair it properly   I also checked for replacement parts on a 2021 Volkswagen Tiguan it‚Äôs a very comparable ICE suv in the VW group so a new replacement engine is 06k 100 035 T $ 8,087.00 not including any accessories like turbocharger injector intake etc just a long block a new transmission is $ 11,784.00 so for the set is $ 19,871.00  all price are in Canadian money just wanted to see the difference in price in a different brand and VS a gasoline equivalent suv.

@motormouth Here's a tidbit you all may not know. MFGs find more and more that the dealership model of bringing cars to market is fraught with issues. For example, the only reason TSB are still dealt through dealerships is because there are clauses in the dealership contracts that mandates that certain types of operations must occur at the dealership level (to protect the business value of the dealership).  Tesla and Polestar do not suffer from this affliction because they do not have dealerships and is one clear advantage other MFGs do not have the luxury to avail themselves. Granted the model has worked in their advantage for decades, today it has become sort of a liability.  This is not solely for the car industry but as a whole. Any recreational vehicle for example (of any brand) will have the same type of contract.   In the specific case here for the battery (and the astronomical, stupid pricing of it), clearly there is gouging involved. There is no way a battery is worth 60k.... not even 20k. It may be a sizeable part of the car but.. come on! I would want to see the margins they have (across all the chain) for this item alone. I would have to say... Probably in the order of 800-1000% (if not more) from original cost of materials and assembly.   Now, for that dealership that didn't even remove the protection cover to inspect the battery... Sorry to hear about this situation! I was an engineer with Hyundai/Kia for almost 20 years and am also a trained automotive repair technician. The hole with the red arrow is NOT an indicator for damage! Nor do you measure the gap as a means of damage! The plastic cover underneath the car is just that, a cover! By covering the underbody with a plastic shield, it will help reduce drag which helps to increase mileage. Hyundai & Kia has been installing these covers on all their vehicles for many years now just to help reduce drag underneath the vehicle. These plastic covers were never meant to protect the underbody. It does offer some protection as a byproduct but again its main purpose is to reduce drag.  If the engineers really wanted to protect the batteries from road hazards, they would have used a metal shield not plastic. I am assuming the dealership tech that reviewed the vehicle did not actually remove the cover (like you had stated in your video). If he had, he may have found no damage to the battery pack.  As a tech, if this had happened to me I would have lifted the vehicle and removed the cover to see for myself. This would require lifting the vehicle high enough to get underneath. Most owners won't have the tools or know-how to do this. So now they are at the mercies of the dealership techs who may not care to do a good job! Hind sight is always 20/20. If this owner would have taken his car to another dealership or independent shop for a second opinion, he might have received a different diagnosis!

I personally had issues with a brand new 2023 Hyundai Ioniq 5 AWD Long range (the top trim), we have 2 EV's, this one was going to be our road tripper as it charges excellently. I took delivery last Oct 2022, 2 weeks later I decided to try the fast DC charging, it failed, turned out I had a defect in the DC charging system, the normal level 2 charging worked, but this eliminated the car from our road tripper. 5 service calls later (at the same dealer) and 5 ferry trips from the Sunshine Coast to North Vancouver (at our expense), and multiple replacement parts of which none repaired the problem, I decided to try another dealer. I have very limited mechanical understanding‚Äîthought a bit more than most people, having worked in Auto Sales, Finance and Management for a long time‚Äîbut I could see long ago that EVs were a ticking time bomb (not in a literal sense, though maybe that too if you consider the inextinguishable Lithium fires like the lady whose Mercedes EQE loaner burnt to a crisp as well as the cargo ship fire caused by EVs--both incidents happened this past Summer).  Anyway, people started buying Hybrids for gas savings and to reduce their carbon footprints. seemed like a win-win and the World, all of a sudden, was a better place. Consumer saves money. Environment stays healthier. Then manufacturers thought: If Hybrids are working out, let's now go to full-EV (not to mention they were also receiving pressure and incentives from government to rush the tech to market but that's a different story). Now just about every manufacturer is selling Hybrids (HEVs), Plug-ins (PHEVs) and Full EVs (BEVs). At a minimum, replacing a hybrid rack of batteries costs $5-$7,000 with the labor. Typical hybrid life is about 10 years give-or-take the battery quality and how the car is driven. This amount of money to replace batteries basically offsets any gas money saved over the course of the past decade. So there's no real monetary savings. Some Hybrid buyers tell themselves, "okay, maybe I'm not saving money but I _am_ saving the environment!" Well...not really. Do some research into extraction (think slave labor in Africa creating monstrous carbon footprints to extract and refine the necessary ores) and recycling (think non-sustainable resources that will create further pollution). So...there's really no upside to the buyer or the environment in Hybrids. As far as Full EVs...well, it's even worse (for buyer and environment). This video says all you need to know. Often, the cost of a rack for a Full EV will far exceed the depreciated cost of a car and the option becomes...get a *new* Full EV for less money (pollute the environment with the old batteries and old car that no wholesaler will touch because they know they have to put tens-of-thousands into in order to resell--not to mention you, the driver coming tens-of-thousands out-of-pocket to get a new one)...or pay more than the cost of a new car just to replace the batteries on your 8-10 year old car.  What was originally viewed as a win-win for driver and Mother Earth is clearly a lose-lose. Want to drive your car forever with little-to-no major repair or replacement costs? Stick to naturally-aspirated (non-turbo). Turbos generate power by taking the exhaust from normal engine combustion and putting it through a turbo to generate more power. But this means heat and pressure--both of which are the worst enemies of your engine's longevity. Stick to manual or automatic (no CVT, no torque converter, no dual-clutch, no intelligent manual transmission) Stick to internal combustion *(NO HYBRIDS, PLUG-INS, OF FULL EVs)*
